techniques.evidence: The attackers initiated the campaign through spearphishing emails containing malicious PDF attachments. These emails were carefully crafted to appear as legitimate diplomatic communications.

The malicious macro utilized obfuscated PowerShell commands to download the next-stage payload from a compromised legitimate website. The PowerShell script executed several commands to establish persistence.
It created a scheduled task that would run daily at system startup, ensuring the malware maintained access even after system reboots.
The attackers modified Windows registry keys to enable further execution capabilities and disable certain security features.
The malware also injected code into legitimate Windows processes to avoid detection.
The attackers deployed credential dumping tools to extract credentials from LSASS memory.
They also utilized keylogging capabilities to capture passwords entered by users during normal operations.

The stolen credentials were then used to access additional systems within the network using legitimate authentication mechanisms, making the lateral movement difficult to distinguish from normal administrative activity.
APT29 moved laterally across the network using Windows Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).
APT29 moved laterally across the network using Windows Remote Desktop Protocol (RDP) and Windows Management Instrumentation (WMI).
Files were compressed into encrypted archives before exfiltration.
Data exfiltration occurred through HTTPS connections to attacker-controlled infrastructure, disguised as normal web traffic.
The attackers used cloud storage services as an additional exfiltration channel, uploading stolen data to compromised cloud accounts.
